thread.title: Customer fatally shoots robber in Charleston Waffle House
thread.title_full: Customer fatally shoots robber in Charleston Waffle House - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Customer fatally shoots robber in Charleston Waffle House
text:
WCSC A customer at this Charleston Waffle House shot and killed an armed robber. WCSC The customer had a permit for his pistol and will not be charged, police said. Previous Next Enlarge A customer at a Waffle House in Charleston, S.C. opened fire on a would-be robber and killed him early Saturday morning — and will not be charged for the shooting, police said.
“No one was hurt, which is the best part,” Waffle House division manager Brandon Rogers told the Post and Courier.
“No one was injured — besides the suspect.”
A Waffle House employee told the paper: “He saved us.”
The thief, 19-year-old Joshua Jermaine Davis, entered the restaurant shortly after 5 a.m., police said. By the time officers arrived, he had been shot. He died later in hospital, WCSC reported.
Davis' Facebook page has several pictures of him posing with a hangun. Four days before the shooting, he posted a picture of what appears to be a police car and wrote, "We see Ya n----."
The unidentified man who shot Davis had a permit to carry his pistol, police said.
Joshua Davis/via Facebook Joshua Davis, 19, was the identified as the robbery suspect. Less than a month before the shooting, he posted this picture on Facebook of him posing with a gun. As the Waffle House manager noted, no one was injured in the shooting except Davis. The restaurant manager said Davis did not steal anything, and the restaurant saw only minor damage from broken glass.
The store was open as usual on Sunday, with an employee telling the Daily News the staff is moving on “as best we can.”
Waffle House reps did not return request for comment.
The shooting comes just weeks after a Waffle House in Kentucky came under fire for denying service to a National Guard soldier in uniform who was carrying a firearm. The soldier, Billy Welch, said he told employees he did not feel comfortable putting the gun away, and told a local station: “You know, if I can’t have my firearm, then I can’t be here.”
After that incident, the company said in a statement it has “a ‘no firearms’ policy.”
jsilverstein@nydailynews.com
